page.title: 02COASTLINE RYDE TO PUCKPOOL
page.content: Walking east from Ryde Boating Lake we come to{Appley.}There is a bay stretching 1km to{Puckpool Point.}At low tide the {Ryde East Sands}stretch 2km out to sea. Walking past the{Ryde {Lifeguard Station}we can see the roof of{St Cecilia's Abbey} where Benedictine nuns live. Originally called {Appley House,}it was built in the 18th Century by a local smuggler called David Boyce. Half way along the coastal path on the sea wall is{Appley {Tower}a folly built like a miniture castle. Bordering the shore the land rises gently and is covered with a variety of trees. Once the parkland of several large mansions it now has{two {public parks, a golf course and two {holiday camps.}At Puckpool Point, in Puckpool Park, are the remains of a{ {coastal mortar battery}completed in 1865.
